title: Task plans
content:
A task plan is a set of tasks in a record's workflow that needs to be completed before moving from one phase of the workflow to the next. A task plan might include automated tasks, manual tasks, and decisions that need to be made by the system to determine which path of the task plan to follow.

A task plan for an approval phase of a workflow is known as an approval plan. An approval plan might include approval tasks and decisions that need to be made by the system to determine which path of the approval plan to follow.

You can build task/approval plans for the following record types:

  • Changes and change models

  • Ideas

  • Proposals

  • Incidents and incident models

  • Offerings and fulfillment plans

  • Articles and article models

  • Problems

  • Releases

  • Requests

  • Agreements

You can add a task plan to specific phases in the workflow of a record. You can only add an approval plan to phases in the workflow that are defined as allowing approval definitions. A phase in a workflow can have either tasks or approvals, but not both.

For record types that have a corresponding "model" record type (Change, Incident, Article, Request), it's a best practice to build task/approval plans on the "model" record types. This way, records created based on the models automatically have consistent task plans and task plan management is more efficient.

By default, any agent user can modify task plans. You can restrict the task plan management responsibility to only a limited set of users (referred to as task plan administrators). This ensures that agent users can focus on completing assigned tasks by following the process defined by task plans and increases your service quality. For details, see the "Control access to task plans" section below.

How to build a task/approval plan

Step 1

In the Agent Interface, open a record, for example, a Request record.

Step 2

Follow the instructions in the table below to open the task/approval plan builder.

Step 3

Select a phase.

  • You can define task plans only for the phases that appear on the Task Plan or Approvals tabs.
  • You can't define task plans for user-defined phases.

Step 4

To start building the task plan, hover over the Start node, and click Edit.

Step 5

Select an element to add to the plan, and enter the relevant information:

Click the Expression Language    buttons to toggle between simple mode and Expression Language mode.

Definitions of manual task/automated task/external task are as follows: 

  • A manual task is a task that must be performed manually by a user.
  • An automated task (available for the non-approval phases only), indicated by the icon, is a task that's performed automatically using business rules.
  • An external task, indicated by the icon, is a task that's only used in the out-of-the-box task plan for cloud offerings to perform an action in the external system. You can't manually add this type of task to a task plan.

For automated tasks, all fields must be defined using one of the following:

  • REST APIs over the On-Premises Bridge. For more information on using the On-Premises Bridge, see On-Premises Bridge Agents and Endpoints.
  • Expression Language. For more information, see Expression Language.

Context record

Field Description
Priority

The priority of the task.

This value is copied from the parent record and automatically filled in by the system.
Requestor

The user who opened the parent record of the task.

This value is copied from the parent record and automatically filled in by the system.

Note that if the parent record is a Problem record, the Requestor field has an empty value by default because this field doesn't exist in the Problem record type.
Service The actual service of the parent record of the task. This value is copied from the parent record and automatically filled in by the system. 

Task properties

Title The name of the task as displayed in the Tasks queue
Description A description of the task
Assignment group

The group assigned to perform the task

Example: Windows Tower team

It's recommended to define an assignment group when defining change models or service/support offerings. You define groups in Administration > Master Data > People > Groups. For more information, see Groups.
Assignee

The user assigned to perform the task

It's a best practice to define this field as an Expression Language phrase.
Requires planning Indicates that planning is required before implementing the task
Requires review Indicates that review is required after implementing the task
Task plan showstopper Failure of the task indicates a showstopper
Cost center The cost center of the task. Select a value from the drop-down list.
Cost type The cost type of the task. Select a value from the drop-down list.

You can use Expression Language expressions to create some parameters that are used in tasks and approvals. You can also choose whether to use the values that are assigned to a task or approval when it's created or when it's run. For example:

  • Approval notifications can display the updated title of the parent record instead of the original title.
  • Approval notifications can be sent to an updated assignee.

By default, the results of Expression Language expressions are calculated only when a task or approval is created. If the results of an expression change after a record is created but before the task or approval has started, the expressions aren't recalculated.

If you want to use the values that are assigned when a task or approval is run, go to Application Settings and edit the Task/approval parameter evaluation field.

In the task plan of the parent record, the agent user can select a task node and expand the Task preview & edit sidebar to preview and edit task properties without leaving the current page. 

Parent record

In the detail form of a task, if the assignee has permission to access the task's parent record, he/she can expand the Parent Record sidebar and view its information without leaving the current page. If the user wants to see more details, the parent record can be easily accessed by clicking the title link.

This Parent record section shows the same content as the preview form of the parent record in the grid view, which can be configured in Administration > Studio > Record type > Preview form.

Scheduling

Note: these fields are informational only, and don't actually change when the task is run.

Planned start date The date the task is to start
Planned end date The date by which the task should be completed
Scheduled downtime start The start time for a downtime period scheduled for the purpose of working on the task
Scheduled downtime end The end time for a downtime period scheduled for the purpose of working on the task

External

This section is relevant when the task is associated with work to be done by an external party.

Field Description
External contact Select the contact representing the external supplier or vendor if they are registered as a contact in Service Management.
External contact detail Enter contact information for the external party. This is especially relevant if they aren't registered as a Service Management contact.
External process reference Enter the ticket ID of the ticket opened with the supplier.

Business rules

Rules that determine when the automated task is instantiated.

  1. Click + Set Rule.

  2. In the Set rule dialog box, select the required rule template from the list. The rule template appears in the Preview section at the bottom of the dialog box, with live links for the parameters. Select or clear the Include condition check box to add or remove a condition for the rule.

  3. When you click a parameter, an edit box appears. Edit the rule by clicking each of the parameters and entering or selecting the required parameter value in the appropriate edit box. Click OK.

    For some rules, only the first parameter is initially editable. After you select a value for the first parameter, the other rule parameters become editable.

  4. Click  Save to save the rule (for automated tasks only).

    For information about adding business rules, see How to add a business rule.

Approval

Requires one or more users to grant an approval before the workflow can move on to the next phase.

Available for the approval phases only.

Title A title for the approval.
Strategy

The strategy to use to obtain the approval:

  • All must approve. Every assigned user must grant an approval.
  • All must approve - immediate deny. Every assigned user must grant an approval. If one user denies an approval, the approval is denied.
  • Quorum. The majority of responses determines whether the approval is granted or denied.
  • One must approve. Requires only one assigned user to grant an approval. The approval is granted regardless of the responses of the other users.

  • One must approve – immediate deny. Requires only one assigned user to grant an approval. If one user denies an approval, the approval is denied. (The decision follows the first user who answers.)
Add approver user Adds a User line to the list of approvers where you can specify a user who must grant the approval.
Add approver group

Adds a Group line to the list of approvers where you can specify a group that must grant the approval.

When a user in the group assigns the approval to himself, the approval is removed from the Approvals queues of the other members of the group.

 If you specify an approver group that contains no members, the approval is automatically approved, regardless of the approval strategy. 
Add approver expression

Adds an Expression line to the list of approvers where you can specify an Expression Language phrase to determine which users must grant an approval.

You can also define a condition on which to base the resulting list of users. The condition is defined as an Expression Language phrase.
By default, business rules add a comment to the record when its approval status changes to Approved or Denied.

To change this, you must update the business rules that control this behavior. You must do this for each record type for which you want to change the behavior. To do this, click Administration > Studio > Processes and Rules in the main menu, select the desired record type, and then search for entity.CurrentApprovalDisplayComment to find the business rules to update.

Decision

A decision point that uses Expression Language phrases to determine which path in the task plan to follow:

  1. Enter the details of the decision to be made.

  2. Enter an Expression Language phrase to define when the decision must be made.

  3. For decisions that require a yes or no answer, you can use the predefined Yes/No decision options.

    Alternatively, click Advanced to define other decision options. In this case, the list of options always includes an otherwise option in case none of the defined options are met.

For each decision option, define the next step.

Step 6

To create a path from one node to another, click the Edit  button on the source node, select Path to, and click the destination node. A path is drawn from the source node to the destination node.

Step 7

To ensure that certain tasks are completed before moving on with another task, you can direct them through a join node. Each task node leading to the join node must be completed before the task node leading out of the join node can be instantiated.

To join nodes:

  1. Click the Edit button on one of the nodes, and select Join. A join node is added.

  2. Click the node that you want to join to the first node, and select Path to.

  3. Click the join node. Both nodes lead to the join node.

  4. Repeat to direct more nodes through the join node if desired.

Step 8

Continue to build the plan in the same way from one node to another.

Step 9

Save the plan.

  • In a task plan or an approval plan, if there is an error with a particular task, an error icon is displayed. Hover over the icon to view the error message. For more information about tasks, see Task queue.
  • In a task plan, you can hover over the plan to view the assignment group or assignee.
  • Due to a product limitation, when creating a task plan, if you want to use a DSL expression for an entity link, the entity link can't be set as a mandatory field. Otherwise, you will receive an error message "xxx should not be empty" when saving the record.  

Approval task status

The following table lists the statuses of an approval task on the Task node.

Status Description
Not running The approval task has not been initiated.
In progress The approval task is in progress.
Approved The approval task has been approved.
Denied The approval task has been denied.
Canceled If the approver decides to cancel the approval task, he/she can set the Task Completion Code to "Cancel" or "SystemCancel." Then, the status of the approval task becomes "Canceled."
Skipped

When there is not a valid approver, the approval task is skipped. For example:

  • The approver is set to an empty group.
  • The approver is set through a DSL expression that returns no user.

Some rules of task nodes

  • If one task node is canceled, another "in progress" task node will be canceled automatically.
  • If one task node is canceled, another "not running" task node won't be executed ever.
  • If one task node is denied, another "in progress" task node will be canceled automatically.
  • If one task node is denied, another "not running" task node won't be executed ever.

SLT calculation for manual tasks

SLT calculation is available for manual tasks. For details, see Service Level Target calculations.

Control access to task plans

You can restrict the ability to manage task plans to only task plan administrators. To achieve this result, do the following as a tenant admin:

  • Add and configure a Restrict/allow editing of fields or Disable fields business rule. After this, when a normal agent user opens the tab for task plans, the user will see a lock displayed next to the task plan phases, and can't perform task plan management tasks; the user can only view details of tasks that make up the task plan.

    See the "How to disable task plan phases by using business rules" section below for configuration details.

  • Assign the Ability to edit locked task plans permission to task plan administrators. This permission can circumvent the limitations imposed by those business rules. This way, only task plan administrators (and tenant admins) can create and manage locked task plans.

How to disable task plan phases by using business rules

You can disable task plan phases by using a "Restrict/allow editing of fields" or "Disable fields" business rule. For both rules, the key is to select the fields that correspond to task plan phases for the record type. The following provides an example for disabling the task plan phases for the Change record type using the "Restrict/allow editing of fields" rule.

  1. From the main menu, navigate to Administration > Studio.

  2. Select Change in the upper left corner.

  3. Go to the Fields tab, and then enter "task" in the search field. Fields whose Name starts with TasksExecutionPlan or TaskPlan correspond to task plan phases. Take note of the Multilingual Label for the fields.

  4. Add a "Restrict/allow editing of fields" rendering rule to the appropriate place. You can add the rule from Studio or from the Rules tab of "model" (such as Change Model, Offering) records.

  5. Click the Restrict/allow link, and then select Restrict from the list.

  6. Click Fields, and then click Add Item multiple times to add the fields identified in Step 3. Depending on your business requirements, you can disable all task plan phases or just certain phases.

  7. Click OK.
